AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.undocumented aliens: individuals suspected of crossing the border illegally, potentially traveling and being stopped based on appearance and other slight circumstances, found in a pickup truck camper with unwashed and unkempt occupants, attempting to hide from view when approached by United States Border Patrol, reacting physically to the beam of a flashlight, including ducking and scrambling in response to a bright light, carried in large numbers such as twenty-two people
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.pickup truck camper: vehicle stopped by United States Border Patrol on Interstate Highway 35, containing undocumented aliens and searched based on probable cause, with fogged windows suggesting living cargo, and noted to be carrying an apparent heavy load, where occupants were observed reacting to a flashlight and scrambling in the interior to avoid detection, exhibiting signs of overloading such as weaving and angled headlights
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.Maria De Jesus Garcia: defendant arguing against the use of the modified Allen charge, claiming it was coercive and seeking post-verdict discovery through juror depositions
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.United States v. Maria De Jesus Garcia: court case involving allegations against Maria De Jesus Garcia, focusing on the modified Allen charge's potential coercive effect and its proper use in this instance, with a review of the record to determine if the Brignoni-Ponce standard is satisfied
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.United States v. Pena-Cantu: court case referenced in the context of the modified Allen charge, rejecting a general attack on the modified Allen charge as being inherently coercive in any form
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.United States v. Pacheco: court case referenced in the context of the modified Allen charge, affirming the decision in United States v. Pena-Cantu
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.United States v. Orona-Sanchez: court case referenced in the context of the modified Allen charge, upholding the use of the modified Allen charge
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.TATE: Circuit Judge, dissenting in United States v. Maria De Jesus Garcia
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.Mexican aliens: individuals suspected of crossing the border illegally, potentially traveling in a crowded pickup truck camper
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.United States-Mexican border: border approximately 100 miles south of where the pickup truck camper was stopped
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.marked United States Border Patrol sedan: law enforcement vehicle used for stopping and searching vehicles near the United States-Mexican border
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.modified Allen charge: judicial instruction given to the jury, potentially coercive as used in this case due to timing and circumstances but found not to be unduly coercive, with its impact on jurors assessed, leading to a guilty verdict after further deliberation
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.jury in United States v. Maria De Jesus: deliberating body that received the modified Allen charge, with dissenting jurors potentially coerced into voting to convict but shown to have heeded the charge's admonition without surrendering their convictions, subject of post-verdict discovery request, returning a verdict after approximately ninety minutes of deliberation following the charge
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.United States District Court: court with discretion over the use of the modified Allen charge and the decision on post-verdict discovery requests
